text:
Somehow, Tomcat will not work properly with J2SDK 1.4.0 and this file (which 
works fine with older versions of Tomcat).
Directions: Install J2SDK 1.4.0.  Install Tomcat.  Put simple.jsp in directory 
and test it.

type Exception report

message Internal Server Error

description The server encountered an internal error (Internal Server Error) 
that prevented it from fulfilling this request.

exception 

org.apache.jasper.JasperException: Unable to compile class for JSPerror: 
Invalid class file format in C:\j2sdk1.4.0\jre\lib\rt.jar
(java/lang/Object.class).  The major.minor version '48.0' is too recent for 
this tool to understand.

C:\Program Files\Apache Tomcat 4.0\work\localhost\_\simple$jsp.java:0: Class 
java.lang.Object not found in class javax.servlet.GenericServlet.
package org.apache.jsp;
^

creator: apowers@andrew.cmu.edu
remm@apache.org
text:
The version of javac you're using doesn't match the one from the JDK. This can 
happen if you're using the Tomcat installer (which copies javac to the Tomcat 
directory), and then upgrade to JDK 1.4.
In any case, Tomcat works fine on JDK 1.4 (at least a clean install does).

creator: gthb@dimon.is
text:
Another way in which this can sneak up on you is if your JAVA_HOME
environment variable doesn't point to the installation that contains
the java command that is earliest in your shell PATH. If your startup
script just uses the command "java" as opposed to "$JAVA_HOME/bin/java"
(on Unix) or "%JAVA_HOME%\bin\java" (on Windows), then you'll be running
the first java in your shell path, but including a tools.jar from another
installation in your classpath! And that can get you ... as it got me. :)
